awd_titl_txt: Developing a 21st Century Training Program in the Florida Keys for Renewable Alternative Energy Technology: Wind, Solar and Tidal Power
awd_abstract_narration:
The need for sustainable, clean, renewable alternative energy is well grounded, as well as the need to establish renewable alternative energy production technologies (e.g. wind and solar power) and increase exploration of new technologies like tidal power. With increasing demands for "solar and wind" jobs, the training needed to create the workforce necessary to sustain the rapid expansion and transition to these new energy production technologies is also needed. Florida Keys Community College (FKCC) is ideally located in one of the sunniest, windiest and tidal energy rich cities in the US.  This project at FKCC will lead to the development of an Associate in Science degree for Engineering Technology that will focus on training Alternative Energy Technicians and conducting research to foster wind, solar and tidal energy technologies locally, regionally, nationally and internationally. As FKCC trains the 21st Century workforce for green energy, conducts research to harness the surrounding renewable energy resources and develops a global network devoted to fostering the renewable energy industry, the Engineering Technology Alternative Energy Technicians (ET-AET) program will be at the epicenter. 

The proposed two year training and research program will join a network of other regional engineering technology programs that will maximize transferability while using unique research opportunities as a training tool for wind, solar and tidal energy. The College has extraordinary infrastructure that makes it perfectly suited for renewable energy training, including a 17,000 square meter lagoon that will be used as a tidal energy simulation laboratory (TESLA). The TESLA facility will allow FKCC to participate in ground breaking tidal energy research by testing prototype tidal energy devices in a controlled yet natural marine environment. The program will include multiple industry certifications and be highlighted by a capstone industry internship that will provide valuable "real world" skills combined with paid professional experience and job placement opportunities. The program partners include a host of national and international renewable alternative energy experts and promises to provide state-of-the-art technology and opportunities for developing global networks, all while fostering the transition from fossil fuels to green energy.

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: THE COLLEGE OF THE FLORIDA KEYS

por.por_cntn:
Final Outcomes Report

At no time in human history has the need to transition from fossil fuel-based power production to clean, green, renewable energy been greater. This urgency is driving the renewable energy industry to expand rapidly, especially in the offshore environments. Recognizing the need to train the 21st century workforce to foster this transition, the College of the Florida Keys (CFK) with support from the National Science Foundation, developed a self-sustaining Associate in Science (AS) degree for Engineering Technology - Renewable Energy Technician (ET-RET) training focused on wind, solar, and hydrokinetic power (i.e. energy from moving water like ocean currents and tides) (Figure 1).The Florida Keys are ideally suited for this type of training because they are surrounded by immense renewable energy resources like the Gulf Stream, which is one of the strongest ocean currents on earth, and the immense tidal energy created as the moon pulls the Atlantic Ocean back and forth into the Gulf of Mexico twice per day between the approximately 1,700 islands and underneath the forty-three bridges that connect Key West to South Florida. Moreover, the city of Key West is 12th sunniest city in the US, and the windiest city in Florida. 

Students in the ET-RET program build upon a strong educational foundation consisting of safety, electronics, computer-aided design (CAD), industrial tools and equipment, quality control, and conceptual physics, before moving into the specialized courses for wind, solar, and hydrokinetic power. During introductory level renewable energy courses students engage in laboratory and research-based training, as well as virtual reality technician training simulations. Towards the end of the 2-year program, students participate on a week long field experience visiting various renewable energy organizations and other academic institutions within the state of Florida. Then finally as the capstone experience for the students, working with industry partners, the conceptual and theoretical information learned is then reinforced and applied during paid-professional internships in a discipline of their choosing (i.e. wind, solar, or hydrokinetic). The success rate of the  ET-RET program is demonstrated by near 100% job placement for graduates.   

Although the ET-RET program provides training for wind and solar technologies (Figures 2 and 3), what separates this program from others is the focus on marine hydrokinetic (MHK) energy technology. The ET-RET program works with industry partners and utilizes applied research as an educational tool and offers internships and research assistantships to develop new renewable energy technicians. The unique infrastructure of the college includes the world?s largest controlled marine test facility for MHK research. With a volume of almost 18 million gallons and measuring 170 m long, 40 m wide and 10 m deep (Figure 4), the MHK-Test Facility (MHK-TF) provides ocean testing is a controlled near-shore environment and access to offshore ocean testing using the CFK Renewable Energy Test Vessel (RETV) (Figures  5 and 6).

The RETV is powered by 100% renewable energy by harnessing the power of the sun with twenty-four 460W solar panels and four (350W) wind generators. The RETV is propelled through the MHK test facility and offshore using four outboard electric engines. The RETV is the pride of the ET-RET program and was designed by industry partners and assembled staff and ET-RET students over the past five years. At the center of the RETV is a 10m2 opening that allows prototype MHK devices and other monitoring equipment to be deployed for energy production research. The RETV will allow technology developers to work with the ET-RET program to conduct initial testing of prototype MHK devices in a controlled near-shore environment, with shore support for troubleshooting any technical issues, before moving offshore for real in-situ ocean testing. As developers utilizes exceptional MHK research and development facility, the program income generated will help sustain the ET-RET program by providing resources for: (1) paid professional internships, (2) research assistantships, (3) student travel to present research findings and network at relative conferences, and (4) maintaining state-of-the-technology training programs.

As the renewable energy industry expands, especially in the offshore marine environment with power production facilities conducting offshore wind, solar, and hydrokinetic power, the highly skilled graduates from the visionary ET-RET program will be in high demand. The ET-RET program, with the associated MHK test facility, and RETV offers a one-of-a-kind renewable energy technician training program and research platform that promises to, not only train the 21st century workforce for renewable energy, but also foster the progress of the renewable energy industry into the future.

 


Last Modified: 12/06/2022
Modified by: Patrick Rice
